text: OF TACITUS. 217 They desired to be led against the enemy, book Their impatience rose to a pitch little short of sedition. It was with difficulty that Galius appeased the tumult. He made halt at Bedriacum (a), a village si- tuated between Verona and Cremona, and unhappily famous for the slaughter of two Roman armies. About the same time the Othonians gained a second advantage over the enemy. Marti us Macer fought with success near Cremona. That officer, with the spirit of enterprise that distinguished him, embarked the gladiators on the Po, and, making a sudden descent on the op- posite bank, fell with fury on the auxilia- ries of Vitellius. All who attempted to make head against him were put to the sword; the rest fled with precipitation to Cremona. Macer was not willing to lose by rashness the fruit of his victory. He knew that, by the arrival of fresh forces, the fortune of the day might be changed, and, for that reason, recalled his men from the pursuit.
